#Text=Nicholas
#Text=Wadham ( 1472 – 1542 )
#Text=For the founder of Wadham College , see Nicholas Wadham ( 1531 – 1609 ) .
#Text=Arms of Wadham : Gules , a chevron between three roses argent [ 1 ]
#Text=Sir Nicholas Wadham

#Text=( by 1472 – 1542 ) of Merryfield in the parish of Ilton , Somerset and Edge in the parish of Branscombe , Devon was the grandfather of Nicholas Wadham ( 1531 – 1609 ) , posthumous co-founder of Wadham College , Oxford whose wife Dorothy Wadham outlived him and , in her advanced old age , saw the project through to completion .

#Text=Originally taking their name from the manor of Wadham , Knowstone between South Molton and Exmoor in north Devon , Nicholas Wadham was descended from an ancient West Country gentry family with a leaning towards the law .

#Text=He was the eldest son and heir of John Wadham ( died 1502 ) of Merryfield and Edge and Elizabeth Stucley , daughter of Sir Hugh Stucley of Affeton Castle and Sheriff of Devon in 1449 , who had married Katherine de Affeton sole heiress of the Manor of Affeton , Nicholas Wadham 's grandmother .

#Text=Sir Nicholas was Member of Parliament for Somerset as a Knight of the Shire with his kinsman Sir William Stourton , 7th Baron Stourton ( c. 1505 – 1548 ) , in the Reformation Parliament of 1529 to 1534 . [ 2 ]
#Text=Nicholas Wadham was Esquire of the Body to King Henry VII ( 1485 – 1509 ) in 1503 , and knighted in 1504 " at ye creacion of Prince Henry " , then only thirteen years of age .
#Text=He was Sheriff of Devon in 1502 and 1515 , Sheriff of Somerset and Dorset in 1498 and 1534 , and Sheriff of Wiltshire in 1516 .

#Text=He was Captain of the Isle of Wight [ 3 ] with residence at Carisbrooke Castle from 1509-1520 , and with his uncle Sir Edward Wadham was present with King Henry VIII ( 1509 – 1547 ) at the Field of the Cloth of Gold , in 1520 . [ 4 ]

#Text=In 1512 , he was one of the Commission for fitting out at Southampton the abortive expedition under Thomas Grey , 2nd Marquess of Dorset ( 1477 – 1530 ) to aid Ferdinand of Aragon in his invasion of France and , from 1521 – 1523 , was Vice Admiral to Thomas Howard , Earl of Surrey ( 1473 – 1554 ) , High Admiral of England from 1521 to 1525 .
#Text=He was granted a patent in 1524 , licensing him " to make a park at Merifield of 200 acres of pasture and 40 acres of woodland " . [ 5 ]
#Text=In 1530 , he was appointed one of the Commissioners for making inquisition into the estates of Cardinal Wolsey . [ 6 ]

#Text=Both Sir Nicholas and his uncle , Sir Edward Wadham , were jurors in Bristol at the indictment for treason in May 1521 of Edward Stafford , 3rd Duke of Buckingham of Thornbury Castle in Gloucestershire . [ 7 ]
#Text=In 1524 , he received an honorary admission to the Middle Temple .
#Text=Marriage and children
#Text=He married four times :

#Text=First to his cousin Joan Hill , a daughter of Robert Hill of Halsway Somerset Bridport Dorset and Houndstone near Yeovil and , of Alice Stourton , one of the three daughters and co-heiresses of John Stourton ( died 1438 ) of the manor of Preston Plucknett , today ( in 2017 ) known as the Abbey Farm House and Abbey Barn , Yeovil , and of Brympton d'Evercy .
#Text=Joan Hill was a great granddaughter of Sir Robert Hill ( died 1426 ) of Shilston Justice of the Common Pleas from 1408 to 1423 and Elisabeth ( sometimes called ' Isabella ' ) Wadham .
#Text=By descent of the Hill , Champernowne and Gilbert families , Nicholas Wadham was a cousin of the Devonshire adventurers Sir Walter Raleigh , Sir Humphrey Gilbert and Sir Richard Grenville .
#Text=Joan ’s sister , Margaret Hill , was married to Sir Hugh Luttrell ( b.1456 ) of Dunster Castle . [ 8 ]

#Text=The Hill sisters were half-sisters maternally of Giles Daubeney , 1st Baron Daubeney of Barrington Court near Ilminster who , along with the Luttrells and Wadhams , was a firm supporter of Henry Tudor , Earl of Richmond , later , King Henry VII .
#Text=Nicholas Wadham 's six children with Joan Hill were :
#Text=John Wadham ( died 1578 )
#Text=, the son and heir of Merryfield and Edge , and father of Nicholas Wadham ( 1531 – 1609 ) co-founder with his wife Dorothy Wadham , of Wadham College , Oxford .
#Text=Laurence Wadham of Merifield , who died in 1522 , and whose only child Nicholas Wadham , married to Dorothy Berkeley of Stoke Gifford , Stoke Park , Bristol died without children . [ 9 ]
#Text=Giles Wadham , Rector of Barton St David .

#Text=Andrew Wadham , " one of the Gentlemen Ushers of the Queen 's grace " to Queen Catherine Parr ; [ 10 ] perhaps , at the behest of her friend and lady-in-waiting , and his kinswoman , Joan Champernowne .
#Text=He was taken into the household of Sir Thomas Cromwell as a young man .
#Text=Married to Anne , daughter of Laurence Saunders he died , without children , in 1550 , at their home Delapré Abbey .
#Text=Mary Wadham , who married Sir Richard Chudleigh of the Manor of Ashton . [ 11 ]
#Text=Elizabeth Wadham , was married twice :
#Text=To Sir Edward Bampfield ( died 1528 ) of Poltimore , Devon . [ 12 ]

#Text=Their son Richard Bampfield ( 1526 – 1594 ) , Sheriff of Devon in 1576 , began construction in 1550 of the Tudor period Poltimore House and , in 1590 , Bampfylde House , Exeter ; along with The Great House , Bristol one of the finest town houses in the West Country in the Elizabethan era .
#Text=She was also married to John Warre of Chipleigh ( Chipley Park , Somerset ) , second son of Sir Richard Warre of Hestercombe .

#Text=Margaret Seymour , Lady Wadham ( died 1520 ) , second wife to Sir Nicholas Wadham and also his distant cousin , was a sister of Sir John Seymour ( 1474 – 1536 ) of Wulfhall , married to Margery Wentworth , parents to Queen Jane Seymour and Edward Seymour , 1st Duke of Somerset ; and thus grandparents to King Edward VI ( 1547 – 1553 ) .

#Text=Margaret Seymour died in 1520 , whilst she and Sir Nicholas were still resident at Carisbrooke Castle where he was governor , and there is a fine monument to her memory in St. Mary 's Church , Carisbrooke on the Isle of Wight .
#Text=They had three children :
#Text=Nicholas Wadham , who died as a baby , in 1508 .
#Text=His monumental chrysom brass is in St Peter 's Church , Ilton Somerset , where he lies buried beneath the arms of Wadham ... and angel wings of Seymour .
#Text=Katherine Wadham , and
#Text=Jane Wadham , first cousins to Queen Jane Seymour and Edward Seymour , Duke of Somerset .
#Text=Both Wadham women became reluctant nuns at Romsey Abbey ; [ 13 ] both appear to have married after the dissolution of the abbey in 1539 .
#Text=Thirdly , Sir Nicholas married Isabel Baynham , daughter of Thomas Baynham of Clearwell , Gloucestershire , widow of Sir Giles Brydges ( died 1511 ) of Coberley , Gloucestershire .
#Text=He married lastly , Joan Lyte ( died 1557 ) , a daughter of Richard Lyte of Lytes Cary Somerset , now maintained by the National Trust ( NT ) , the widow of William Walton of Barton St David .
#Text=There is a monumental brass to Dame Joan Wadham in St Peter 's Church , Ilton .

#Text=There were apparently no children by his third and fourth marriages [ 14 ] although his will , written in 1539 , leaves " to my son Nicholas , my third best horse " and a hundred pounds . [ 15 ]
#Text=Given that his son Nicholas by Margaret Seymour died as a baby and was buried at Ilton in 1508 , this remains something of a mystery .
#Text=Notes and references
